./.title: Welcome!
./.body:
Welcome!
This is Red Hat Fuse v7 TestDrive, where you will be able to get hands-on experience on Red Hat's Integration Platform as a Service (Ignite) through step-by-step labs.

intro.html.title: Intro
intro.html.body:
Intro
Ignite is an integration platform. With Ignite, you can obtain data from an application or service, operate on that data if you need to, and then send the data to a completely different application or service. No coding is required to accomplish this.
1. How Ignite works
Ignite lets you enable data transfer between different applications. For example, each time a customer is mentioned in Twitter, you might want to capture that mention in your Salesforce account for that customer. Another example is a service that makes stock trade recommendations. You can capture recommendations of interest and forward them to a service that automates stock transfers.
Ignite provides a web browser interface that lets you integrate two or more different applications or services without writing code. It also provides features that allow you to introduce code if it is needed for complex use cases.
To create and run a simple integration, the main steps are:

Create a connection to each application that you want to integrate. 
Select the start connection. This connection is to the application that contains the data that you want to share with another application. 
Select the finish connection. This connection is to the application that receives data from the start connection and that completes the integration. 
Map data fields from the start connection to data fields in the finish connection. 
Give the integration a name. 
Click Publish to start running the integration. The Ignite dashboard lets you monitor and manage integrations. You can see which integrations are running, start, stop, and edit integrations.

1.2. Who Ignite is for
Ignite is for business experts in, for example, finance, human resources, or marketing, who do not want to write code in order to share data between two different applications. Their use of a variety of software-as-a-service (SaaS) applications gives them an understanding of business requirements, workflows, and relevant data.
1.3. Benefits of Ignite
With Ignite, you can:
Integrate data from different applications or services without writing code. Run the integration on OpenShift in the public cloud or on site. Use the visual data mapper to map data fields in one application to data fields in another application. Leverage all the benefits of open source software. You can extend features, and customize interfaces. If Ignite does not provide a connector for an application or service that you want to integrate then a developer can create the connector that you need.

pre-requisites.html.title: Pre-Requisites
pre-requisites.html.body:
Pre-Requisites
To fulfill this TestDrive you need an Openshift environment that can be provisioned through _____ or created using the scripts in https://github.com/pszuster/Fuse7TD/tree/master/scripts on your own Openshift cluster (or minishift).
When attending a TestDrive, after privisioning an environment, you will get a instance id (GUID) that is unique for you, and will be referenced as  throughout the lab instructions.
Finally, to complete this labs, you will only need a web browser.

rh-fuse-ignite-console-overview.html.title: RH Fuse Ignite Console Overview
rh-fuse-ignite-console-overview.html.body:
RH Fuse Ignite Console Overview
When you log in to Fuse Ignite, you see a console like this:

In the Home tab there is useful information for the administrator of the iPaaS like:

General Statistics
Number of successful/failed integrations
Number of defined connections
Total number of processed messages (successful/failed)
System Uptime





Top used integrations in the last 30 days.



Published/Unpublished integrations.



Recent Updates.



Connections.


In the Integrations tab you will find a list of the existing integrations.

In the Connections tab you will find a list of available connections.

In the Customizations tab you will be able to create API Client Connectors to interact with Swagger-based APIs, and import your custom (or community) Ignite Extensions (steps and connections) to further expand Fuse Ignite functionality.

Finally in the Settings tab, you will be able to manage OAuth Applications (like Salesforce, twitter, APIs, etc).

untitled.html.title: Lab #0 - Setup
untitled.html.summary: In this lab you will setup the environment to start working on the labs
untitled.html.body:
Lab #0 - Setup

Open a web browser, and go to .generic.opentlc.com">https://fuse-ignite.apps-.generic.opentlc.com
Login as admin/admin



Click on the Allow selected permissions button.



Download a zip file with the required assets for the labs in https://minhaskamal.github.io/DownGit/#/home?url=https://github.com/pszuster/Fuse7TD/tree/master/Labs
Unzip the Labs.zip file.

lab-1-files/.title: Lab #1 - Files
lab-1-files/.body:
Lab #1 - Files

Open a web browser, and go to .generic.opentlc.com">https://fuse-ignite.apps-.generic.opentlc.com
Login as admin/admin

lab-1-files/create-ftp-connection.html.title: Create FTP connection
lab-1-files/create-ftp-connection.html.body:
Create FTP connection

Click on the Connections tab.
Click on the Create Connection button.



Select FTP.



Enter the following values:




Host
vsftpd.ftp.svc.cluster.local




User Name
admin


Password
password


Port
21




Click on the Validate button.



You should receive a message like this:



Click on the Next> button.



Enter "Openshift FTP" as the name for the connector.
Click on the Create button.

lab-1-files/untitled.html.title: Create FTP to FTP Integration
lab-1-files/untitled.html.body:
Create FTP to FTP Integration

Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the Create Integration button.



Select Openshift FTP as the starting connection for the integration.



Select the only available action: Download.



Enter the following values:




File name expression
file1.xml




FTP directory
incoming


Delete file after download
Yes




Click on the Next button.



Click on the Done button.



Select Openshift FTP as the finish connection.



Select the only available action: Upload.



Enter the following values:




File name expression
${date:now:yyyyMMdd}.xml




FTP directory
outgoing




Click on the Next button.



Click on the Done button.
Click on the Publish button.



Enter FTP to FTP as the integration name.
Click on the Publish button.


After ~5min the deployment of the integration should be done.

lab-1-files/test-the-integration.html.title: Test the integration
lab-1-files/test-the-integration.html.body:
Test the integration

Go to .generic.opentlc.com">http://ftp.apps-.generic.opentlc.com
Click on Advanced Login
Enter the following values:




Host
vsftpd.ftp.svc.cluster.local




Port
21


Username
admin


Password
password


Passive mode
Checked




Click on the Login button.



Click on the incoming folder.
Upload Labs\Lab1\file1.xml to the FTP server.



Click on the Submit button.



Click on the Back arrow button.
Navigate to the Outgoing folder.
You should have a file with the current date as filename.



Go back to Fuse Ignite  console.
Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the Activity tab.


Notice that there's been one activity in the deployed integration


Click on the Metrics tab.


In the metrics section, you can see one message has been processed by the deployed integration.

lab-1-files/housekeeping.html.title: HouseKeeping
lab-1-files/housekeeping.html.body:
HouseKeeping

Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the three dots in the "FTP to FTP" integration.
Click on Unpublish.
Click YES in the confirmation dialog.

lab-2-data-mapping/.title: Lab #2 - Data Mapping
lab-2-data-mapping/.body:
Lab #2 - Data Mapping

Open a web browser, and go to .generic.opentlc.com">https://fuse-ignite.apps-.generic.opentlc.com
Login as admin/admin

lab-2-data-mapping/create-a-dropbox-acco.title: Create a DropBox account
lab-2-data-mapping/create-a-dropbox-acco.body:
Create a DropBox account
If you don't have a DropBox account, follow these steps:

Go to http://www.dropbox.com/register
Enter your personal details.
Click on the **`Create an account`**button.



Go to your mail inbox and validate the account.

lab-2-data-mapping/create-a-dropbox-app..title: Create a DropBox App
lab-2-data-mapping/create-a-dropbox-app..body:
Create a DropBox App

Click on the three dots, and select Developers.



Click on "MyApps".



Click on the Create App button.



Enter the following values:




API
DropBox API




Type of Access
App Folder


Name
IgniteApp




Click on the Create app button.



Go to the OAuth2 section and click on the Generate button.



Take note of the generated access token. (copy it to a notepad or similar)

lab-2-data-mapping/create-a-dropbox-conn.title: Create a DropBox connection
lab-2-data-mapping/create-a-dropbox-conn.body:
Create a DropBox connection

Click on the Connections tab.
Click on the Create Connection button.



Select the Dropbox connector.



Paste the access token generated in dropbox.com
Enter "IgniteApp" as the Client Identifier.
Click on the Validate button.
Click on the Next button.



Enter "DropboxIgnite" as the Connection Name.
Click on the Create button.

lab-2-data-mapping/create-an-ftp-to-drop.title: Create an FTP to Dropbox Integration
lab-2-data-mapping/create-an-ftp-to-drop.body:
Create an FTP to Dropbox Integration

Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the Create Integration ``button.



Select Openshift FTP as the start connection.



Select the only available action: Download
Enter the following values:




File Name Expression
customer.xml




FTP Directory
incoming


Delete file after download
Yes




Click on the Next button.



Select XML Instance as Type.
Paste the contents of the Labs\Lab2\customer.xml in the Definition field.


  Pablo Szuster
  Ing. Butty 240



Enter Customer as Data Type Name.
Click on the Done button.



Select DropboxIgnite as the finish connection.
Select the only available action: Upload.
Enter /customer.json as Remote Path.
Click on the Next button.



Select JSON Instance as Type.
Paste the contents of Labs\Lab2\customer.json into the Definition field.

{
"customer": {"id": "","firstName": "", "lastName": "","address":""}
}


Enter Customer_JSON as Data Type Name.
Click on the Done button.


Notice there is a warning icon next to the finish connection. This is because its input data shape is different than the start connector's output data shape.


Click on the warning icon in the finish connection.
Click on the `**Add a data mapping step`** link.



Expand both the Source and Target data shapes.
Click on the @id field in the Source data shape.
Click on the id field in the Target data shape.



Click on the address field in the Source data shape.
Click on the address field in the Target data shape.
Click on the Add Transformation button.



Select the Uppercase transformation.



Click on the name field in the Source data shape.
Click on the firstName field in the Target data shape.



Go to the Action section in Mapping Details.
Select Separate as the action.
Leave the default separator (Space[ ]).
Click on the Add Target button.



Click on the new Target field and enter "lastName".
Select the field suggestion



Click on the Done button.
Click on the Publish button.
Enter FTP to DropBox as integration name.
Click on the Publish button.

lab-2-data-mapping/test-the-integration..title: Test the integration
lab-2-data-mapping/test-the-integration..body:
Test the integration

Wait until the integration is published:



Go to .generic.opentlc.com">http://ftp.apps-.generic.opentlc.com
Click on Advanced Login
Enter the following values:




Host
vsftpd.ftp.svc.cluster.local




Port
21


Username
admin


Password
password


Passive mode
Checked




Click on the Login button.



Click on the incoming folder.
Click on the Upload button.



Upload Lab2\customer.xml to the FTP server.
Click on the Submit button.



Click on the Back arrow button.
Go back to Fuse Ignite console.
Click on the Activity tab.


You can see a detail of every processed message


Click on the Metrics tab.



Open a browser tab and go to your dropbox.com account.
Go to My Files -> Apps -> IgniteApp
There should be a customer.json file.



Double-click on the file to see its contents.

lab-2-data-mapping/housekeeping.html.title: HouseKeeping
lab-2-data-mapping/housekeeping.html.body:
HouseKeeping

Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the three dots in the "FTP to Dropbox" integration.
Click on Unpublish.
Click YES in the confirmation dialog.

lab-3-database/.title: Lab #3 - Salesforce to Database
lab-3-database/.body:
Lab #3 - Salesforce to Database

Open a web browser, and go to .generic.opentlc.com">https://fuse-ignite.apps-.generic.opentlc.com
Login as admin/admin

lab-3-database/create-a-salesforce-accou.title: Create a Salesforce account
lab-3-database/create-a-salesforce-accou.body:
Create a Salesforce account

Go to https://developer.salesforce.com/signup and create a free developer account.



Go to your mail inbox and confirm the new account.
Set a password for the account.
Login to your Salesforce account.
Click on the Profile icon (upper-right side).
Click on the Switch to Salesforce Classic link.



Click on the Setup link



Go to the Build section and expand Create.
Click on the Apps link.



Scroll down to the Connected Apps section.
Click on the New button.



Enter the following values:




Connected App Name
IgniteApp




API Name
IgniteApp


Contact Email






Scroll down to the API (Enable OAuth Settings) area.
Click on the Enable OAuth Settings checkbox.
Add the following OAuth Scopes:

Access and manage your data (api)
Perform requests on your behalf at any time(refresh_token,offline_acces)





Click on the Enable for Device Flowcheckbox.
Enter https://fuse-ignite.ignite1.rhtechofficelatam.com/api/v1/credentials/callback as Callback URL.



Click on the Save button.



Take note of the Consumer Key and Consumer Secret (you will need them later).

lab-3-database/create-salesforce-connect.title: Create a Salesforce connection
lab-3-database/create-salesforce-connect.body:
Create a Salesforce connection

Go back to Fuse Ignite console.
Click on the Settings tab (left-hand side).
Click on the Register button in the Salesforce settings.



Enter the following values:




Client ID





Client Secret





Click on the Save button.
Click on the Ok button.



Click on the Connections tab.
Click on the Create Connection button.
Select Salesforce connector.

Make sure ~10mins have passed since creating the Salesforce Connected App.


Click on the Connect Salesforce button.
Login with your recently created Salesforce.com credentials.
Click on the Allow button.



Enter "IgniteSalesforce" as the Connection Name.
Click on the Create button.

lab-3-database/create-a-db-connection.ht.title: Create a DB connection
lab-3-database/create-a-db-connection.ht.body:
Create a DB connection

Click on the Connections tab.
Click on the Create Connection button.
Select the Databaseconnector.



Enter the following values:




Connection URL
jdbc:postgresql://ignitedb.db.svc.cluster.local:5432/JBossBank




Username
admin


Password
password




Click on the Validate button.
Click on the Next button.



Enter " IginteDB"  as Connection Name.
Click on the Create button.

lab-3-database/create-a-salesforce-to-da.title: Create a Salesforce to Database integration
lab-3-database/create-a-salesforce-to-da.body:
Create a Salesforce to Database integration

Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the Create Integration button.
Select  IgniteSalesforce as start connection.



Select On Createaction.
Select Contact as Object name.
Click on the Done button.



Select IgniteDB as finish connection.



Select Invoke SQL as action.
Enter the following value:




SQL Statement
INSERT INTO Contacts(first_name,last_name,email,lead_source) values(:#first,:#last,:#email,:#lead)









Click on the Done button.



Click on the warning icon next to the INVOKE SQL connection.
Click on the Add a data mapping step link.



Perform the following mappings:




Source
Target




FirstName
first


LastName
last


Email
email


LeadSource
lead




Click on the Done button.



Click on the Publish button.
Enter SalesforceToDB as Integration Name.
Click on the Publish button.

lab-3-database/test-the-integration/.title: Test the integration
lab-3-database/test-the-integration/.body:
Test the integration

To test this integration, you will check that the table in PostgreSQL is empty, then create a Salesforce.com contact and finally verify that there is a new record in the DB table.

lab-3-database/test-the-integration/chec.title: Check that DB table is empty
lab-3-database/test-the-integration/chec.body:
Check that DB table is empty

Go to .generic.opentlc.com">http://db.apps-.generic.opentlc.com
Login as:
User: admin@ignite.com
Password: password


Click on  Add New Server.



Enter igniteDB as Name.



Click on the Connection tab.
Enter the following values:




Host
ignitedb.db.svc.cluster.local




Port
5432


Username
admin


Password
admin




Click on the Save button.



Expand Servers -> IgniteDB -> Databases -> JBossBank -> Schemas -> Public -> Tables
Right-click on the contacts table, and select View/Edit Data -> All Rows.


Note that the table is empty.

lab-3-database/test-the-integration/unti.title: Create Salesforce Contact
lab-3-database/test-the-integration/unti.body:
Create Salesforce Contact

Login to Salesforce.com with your credentials
Click on the Contacts tab.
Click on the New button.



Enter the following values:




First Name
Juan




Last Name
Perez


Email
jperez@mail.com


Lead Source
Web




Click on the Save button.

lab-3-database/test-the-integration/chec.title: Check DB Table
lab-3-database/test-the-integration/chec.body:
Check DB Table

Go to .generic.opentlc.com">http://db.apps-.generic.opentlc.com again.
Login as 
Username: admin@ignite.com
Password: password


Expand Servers -> IgniteDB -> Databases -> JBossBank -> Schemas -> Public -> Tables
Right-click on the contacts table, and select View/Edit Data -> All Rows.
You should see a new record in the table:

lab-3-database/housekeeping.html.title: HouseKeeping
lab-3-database/housekeeping.html.body:
HouseKeeping

Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the three dots in the "SalesforceToDB" integration.
Click on Unpublish.
Click YES in the confirmation dialog.

lab-4-salesforce-to-api/.title: Lab #4 - Salesforce to API
lab-4-salesforce-to-api/.body:
Lab #4 - Salesforce to API

Open a web browser, and go to .generic.opentlc.com">https://fuse-ignite.apps-.generic.opentlc.com
Login as admin/admin

lab-4-salesforce-to-api/create-an-api-co.title: Create an API Connector
lab-4-salesforce-to-api/create-an-api-co.body:
Create an API Connector

Click on the  Customizations tab.
Click on the Create API Connector button.



Click on the Choose Filebutton.
Select Lab4/contract_api.json.
Click on the Next button.



Click on the  Next button.


Ignite parses the swagger document, and identifies all the available operations. 
More info about  swagger: https://swagger.io/


Click on the Next button.



Enter the following values:




Connector Icon
Choose File button and select Lab4\opencrx.gif>




Connector Name
OpenCRX


Description
OpenCRX API


Host
http://opencrx.opencrx.svc.cluster.local:8080




Click on the Create API Connector button.

lab-4-salesforce-to-api/create-an-api-co.title: Create an API Connection
lab-4-salesforce-to-api/create-an-api-co.body:
Create an API Connection

Click on the Connections tab.
Click on the  Create Connection button.
Select the OpenCRXconnector.



Enter the following values:




Username
guest




Password
guest




Click on the  Next button.



Enter OpenCRX as Connection Name.
Click on the Create button.

lab-4-salesforce-to-api/create-a-salesfo.title: Create a Salesforce to API integration
lab-4-salesforce-to-api/create-a-salesfo.body:
Create a Salesforce to API integration

Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the Create Integration button.
Choose IgniteSalesforce as  start connection.
Select On Create action.
Select Lead as Object Name.
Click on the Done button.



Select OpenCRX as finish connection.
Select POST /lead as action.



Click on the Done button.



Hover over the + icon between start/finish connections.
Click on the Add a Step link.



Select Data Mapper.
Perform the following mappings:




Source
Target




Description
description


Id
contractNumber


Company
name




In the Company -> name mapping details, select Combine action.
Select Dash[-]Separator.



Hold Ctrl key and click on the ProductIterest_c Source field.



Click on the Done button.
Click on the Publish button.
Enter SalesforceToAPI as Integration Name.
Click on the Publish button.

lab-4-salesforce-to-api/test-the-integra.title: Test the Integration
lab-4-salesforce-to-api/test-the-integra.body:
Test the Integration

To test this integration, you will verify there are no leads in OpenCRX, then create a sales lead in Salesforce.com and finally validate there is a new lead in OpenCRX.

lab-4-salesforce-to-api/test-the-integra.title: Check OpenCRX Leads
lab-4-salesforce-to-api/test-the-integra.body:
Check OpenCRX Leads

Go to .generic.opentlc.com/opencrx-core-CRX/">http://opencrx.apps-.generic.opentlc.com/opencrx-core-CRX/
Login as:
Username: guest
Password: guest


Click on the Sales tab.


Note that there are no existing leads.

lab-4-salesforce-to-api/test-the-integra.title: Create Salesforce Lead
lab-4-salesforce-to-api/test-the-integra.body:
Create Salesforce Lead

Go to salesforce.com
Login with your credentials.
Click on the Leads tab.



Click on the New button.



Enter the following values:




Last Name
Perez




Company
RHBank


Product Interest
GC1000 series (or any other value)


Description
Interested in new products




Click on the Save button.

lab-4-salesforce-to-api/test-the-integra.title: Check OpenCRX Leads
lab-4-salesforce-to-api/test-the-integra.body:
Check OpenCRX Leads

Go to .generic.opentlc.com/opencrx-core-CRX/">http://opencrx.apps-.generic.opentlc.com/opencrx-core-CRX/
Login as:
Username: guest
Password: guest


Click on the Sales tab.




You should see a new lead with all the information coming from Salesforce.

If you don't see any new leads, try refreshing the screen (F5).

lab-4-salesforce-to-api/housekeeping.htm.title: HouseKeeping
lab-4-salesforce-to-api/housekeeping.htm.body:
HouseKeeping

Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the three dots in the "SalesforceToAPI" integration.
Click on Unpublish.
Click YES in the confirmation dialog.

lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/.title: Lab #5 - Red Hat AMQ to API
lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/.body:
Lab #5 - Red Hat AMQ to API

Open a web browser, and go to .generic.opentlc.com">https://fuse-ignite.apps-.generic.opentlc.com
Login as admin/admin

lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/create-an-red-h.title: Create an Red Hat AMQ connection
lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/create-an-red-h.body:
Create an Red Hat AMQ connection

Click on the Connections tab.
Click on the Create Connection button.
Select the AMQ connector.



Enter the following values:




Broker URL
tcp://broker-amq-tcp.amq.svc.cluster.local.61616




User Name
admin


Password
password


Check Certificates
Disable




Click on the Validate button.
Click on the Next button.



Enter "AMQ Broker" as Connection Name.
Click on the Create button.

lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/create-an-amq-t.title: Create an AMQ to API integration
lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/create-an-amq-t.body:
Create an AMQ to API integration

Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the Create Integration button.



Select AMQ Broker as the start connection.
Select the Subscribe for messages action.



Enter the following values:




Destination name
invoices




Destination Type
Queue




Click on the Next button.



Click on the Done button.
Select the OpenCRX connection.
Select the POST /invoice action.



Click on the Done button.
Hover over the + icon and click on the  Add a Step link.
Select the Log step.



Check Message Body.
Enter "INVOICE" as Custom Text. 
Click on the Done  button.



Hover over the + icon and click on the Add a Step link.
Select the Split step.
Enter the following values:




Expression
//invoice




Language
xpath




Click on the Done button.



Hover over the + icon and click on the Add a connection.
Select DataShape connector.
Select the Datashape Endpoint action.
Click on the Next button.
Select XML Instance as the Output Data Type.
Copy and paste Labs\lab5\invoice.xml into the definition field.
EnterInvoiceXML as the Data Type Name.
Click  on the Done button.



Click on the warning icon in the finish connector.
Click on the Add a data mapping step link.



Expand InvoiceXML -> invoice in the Source data structure.
Expand Request -> body -> org.opencrx.kernel.contract1.Invoice in the Target data structure.



Perform the following mappings:




invoiceDescription
description




invoiceName
name


@number
contractNumber


totalAmountIncludingTax
totalAmountIncludingTax


totalBaseAmount
totalBaseAmount


totalTaxAmount
totalTaxAmount





Click on the + icon in the Constants tab.



Enter the following:




Value
true




Value Type
Boolean




Click on the Save button.



Click on the true constant and map it to noAutoRecalc.



Click on the Done button.
Click on the Publish button.
Enter "AMQtoAPI" as integration name.
Click on the Publish button.

lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/test-the-integr.title: Test the integration
lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/test-the-integr.body:
Test the integration
To test this integration you will validate there are no invoices in OpenCRX, then you will send an AMQ message with several invoices in XML format, and finally verify there are new invoices created in OpenCRX.

lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/test-the-integr.title: Check OpenCRX Invoices
lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/test-the-integr.body:
Check OpenCRX Invoices

Go to .generic.opentlc.com/opencrx-core-CRX/">http://opencrx.apps-.generic.opentlc.com/opencrx-core-CRX/
Login as:
Username: guest
Password: guest


Click on the Sales tab.
Click on the Invoices tab.


Note that there are no existing invoices.

lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/test-the-integr.title: Send an AMQ message.
lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/test-the-integr.body:
Send an AMQ message.

Go to .generic.opentlc.com:8443/console/project/rhdg/overview">https://fuseignite-.generic.opentlc.com:8443/console/project/rhdg/overview
Login as admin/admin.
Click on the blue circle.



Click on the Open Java Console link.



Click on the User icon, and Preferences.



Click on the ActiveMQ tab.
Enter the following values:




Activemq user name
admin




Activemq password
password




Click on the Done button.



Click on the invoices queue.
Click on the Send tab.



Paste the contents of Labs\lab5\invoices.xml .
Make sure Payload Format is set to XML.
Click on the Send message button.

lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/test-the-integr.title: Check OpenCRX invoices
lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/test-the-integr.body:
Check OpenCRX invoices

Go to .generic.opentlc.com/opencrx-core-CRX">http://opencrx.apps-.generic.opentlc.com/opencrx-core-CRX
Login as:
Username: guest
Password: guest




Click on the Sales tab.
Click on the Invoices tab.


There should be one invoice per XML invoice element sent in the AMQ message.

lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/test-the-integr.title: Check Integration activity
lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/test-the-integr.body:
Check Integration activity

Go to .generic.opentlc.com/">https://fuse-ignite.apps-.generic.opentlc.com/
Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the AMQtoAPI integration.
Click on the Activity tab.
Expand the first **activity.


Note that for each processed transaction there will be an acitivy log with detailed information about each executed step.

lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/housekeeping.ht.title: HouseKeeping
lab-5-red-hat-amq-to-api/housekeeping.ht.body:
HouseKeeping

Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the three dots in the "AMQtoAPI" integration.
Click on Unpublish.
Click YES in the confirmation dialog.

lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/.title: Lab #6 - HTTP+CSV to RH Data Grid
lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/.body:
Lab #6 - HTTP+CSV to RH Data Grid

Open a web browser, and go to .generic.opentlc.com">https://fuse-ignite.apps-.generic.opentlc.com
Login as admin/admin

lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/create-ht.title: Create an HTTP Connection
lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/create-ht.body:
Create an HTTP Connection

Click on the Connections tab.
Click on the Create Connection button.
Select the HTTP Connector



Enter the following value:
Base URL: http://stockapp.stockapp.svc.cluster.local:8080/stock/


Click on the Validate button.
Click on the Next button.



Enter "stockApp" as the Connection Name.
Click on the Create button.

lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/create-re.title: Create Red Hat Data Grid - HTTP connection
lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/create-re.body:
Create Red Hat Data Grid - HTTP connection

Click on the Connections tab.
Click on the Create Connection button.
Select the HTTP Connector



Enter the following value:

Base URL: http://stockcache.rhdg.svc.cluster.local:8080/rest/stock/


Click on the Validate button.

Click on the Next button.



Enter "RH DataGrid - Stock" as Connection Name.
Click on the Create button.

lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/import-cs.title: Import "CSV to JSON" Extension
lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/import-cs.body:
Import "CSV to JSON" Extension

Click on the Customizations tab.
Click on the Extensions tab.
Click on theImport Extension button.



Click on the Choose File button and selectLabs\Lab6\csvtojson-1.0.0.jar .
Click on the Import Extension button.


You can augment Fuse Ignite capabilities through the creation of extensions developed in Java or Camel routes.


This imported extension was developed using Apache Camel, in JBoss Developer Studio, where there is a visual tool to do this.



Receive CSV message.
Parse CSV according to the column list parameter.
Transform parsed CSV to JSON.

lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/create-an.title: Create an HTTP(CSV) to Red Hat Data Grid integration
lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/create-an.body:
Create an HTTP(CSV) to Red Hat Data Grid integration

Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the Create Integration button.



Select stockApp as the start connection.



Select the only available action:  Periodic invoke URL.
Enter the following values:




URL Path
store_1




Period
60




Click on the Next button.



Select RH Data Grid - Stock as the finish connection.
Select the only available action:  Invoke URL.
Enter the following values:




URL Path
store_1




Http Method
PUT




Click on the Next button.
Click on the Done button.



Click on the Add a Step button.
Select the Process CSV step.
Enter the following value:
CSV Column List: sku,prod_name,prod_sotck,store_id


Click on the Done button.



Click on the Publish button.
Enter "HTTP to RH Data Grid" as integration name.
Click on the Publish button.

lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/test-the-.title: Test the Integration
lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/test-the-.body:
Test the Integration
To test this integration you will first visualize the CSV document returned by the HTTP web service, and then, verify it's content was transformed to JSON and uploaded to Red Hat Data Grid.

lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/test-the-.title: Check HTTP stock service
lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/test-the-.body:
Check HTTP stock service

Go to .generic.opentlc.com/stock/store\_1">http://stock.apps-.generic.opentlc.com/stock/store\_1
You should receive a CSV document with the current stock for store "store_1".

lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/test-the-.title: Check Red Hat Data Grid cache
lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/test-the-.body:
Check Red Hat Data Grid cache

Go to .generic.opentlc.com/rest/stock/store\_1">http://rhdg.apps-.generic.opentlc.com/rest/stock/store\_1
You should see a JSON document with the updated stock information.



If you refresh the page (after 1min), stock information should be updated.

lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/housekeep.title: HouseKeeping
lab-6-http+csv-to-rh-data-grid/housekeep.body:
HouseKeeping

Click on the Integrations tab.
Click on the three dots in the "HTTP to RH Data Grid" integration.
Click on Unpublish.
Click YES in the confirmation dialog.
